title: 103_s1960
content: The Act is titled the "Indian Housing Development and Reform Act of 1994". It includes findings related to Indian housing development. The Congress recognizes the housing crisis faced by Indian tribes, with a lack of shelter for individuals and families, including elderly persons, persons with disabilities, and families with children. The demand for Indian housing is expected to worsen without more effective efforts and consistent funding, endangering the lives of Native people. The Federal Government has a special legal relationship and trust responsibility to provide decent, safe, sanitary, and affordable housing to members of Indian tribes on reservations. The Inspector General of the Department of the Interior has found severe mismanagement and abuse in the Housing Improvement Program, leading to ineligible individuals receiving assistance while eligible ones are not. The transfer of the program to the Department of Housing and Urban Development aims to eliminate bureaucracy and waste. The Housing Improvement Program is being transferred to the Department of Housing and Urban Development to eliminate bureaucracy and waste, ensuring the program's intended goals are met. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines key terms such as Department, Indian, Indian housing authority, Indian tribe, Program, and Secretary. SEC. 4. HOUSING IMPROVEMENT PROGRAM. The Housing Improvement Program is now under the Department of Housing and Urban Development for efficiency and goal achievement. The Program is transferred to the Department with goals to benefit Indian families by providing safe shelter and reducing health and social costs. It includes renovations, repairs, and additions to existing Indian houses to ensure safety and standard conditions. The Secretary administers the Program in accordance with the section, providing assistance only to the governing body of an Indian tribe. The Secretary can modify the Program to meet its goals, and assets and liabilities are transferred as needed. The assets, liabilities, contracts, property, records, and unexpended funds of the Program are transferred to the Department, to be used for their original purposes. Personnel necessary for Program administration are also transferred to the Department, with no separation or reduction in grade or compensation for one year. The transfer of personnel to the Department under this section shall not result in separation or reduction in grade or compensation for one year, except for Executive Schedule employees. The transfer of personnel to the Department under this section shall not result in separation or reduction in grade or compensation for one year, except for Executive Schedule employees. Appointed individuals in comparable positions will continue to be compensated at the previous rate. Presidential appointees in transferred positions will terminate on the effective date. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget is authorized to make necessary determinations and dispositions. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget is authorized to make necessary determinations and dispositions for the termination of entities and legal documents related to the Program. The provisions of this section state that any actions or regulations transferred under the Program will remain in effect until modified or revoked by the President, Secretary, court, or by operation of law. This does not affect any ongoing proceedings or applications before the Department of the Interior. The Program's proceedings and applications before the Department of the Interior will continue as if this section had not been enacted. Orders issued in these proceedings will remain in effect until modified, terminated, or revoked by authorized officials or by law. This section does not prevent the discontinuance or modification of ongoing proceedings. (j) Nonabatement of Actions.--Actions commenced before the effective date of subsection (a)(1) shall proceed without interruption, including appeals and judgments. No action against the Department of the Interior or its officers will be affected by the enactment of this section. Administrative actions related to regulations may continue as usual. The Secretary has the authority to manage the transition effectively. The Secretary is authorized to utilize Department of the Interior personnel and funds for the Program. References to the Secretary and Department of the Interior in federal laws will be deemed to refer to the Secretary and Department, respectively. The Secretary will establish necessary requirements through published regulations in the Federal Register. The Secretary will establish requirements in the Federal Register to carry out the Program, with final regulations issued after public comment. $34,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 1996-2000 for the Program. "Authorization for additional budget authority under the United States Housing Act of 1937 to reserve funds for public housing grants for Indian families, providing assistance for 4,000 units of Indian housing annually from 1996 to 2000. Eligibility criteria for Indians will be established by the Secretary." Section 201 of the United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to limit low-income housing on Indian reservations to Indian low-income families, with an exception for non-Indian families if deemed necessary by the Indian housing authority. Existing assistance to families served by an Indian housing authority on the date of enactment of this subsection is not affected by the new limitations on low-income housing for Indian reservations. SEC. 7 of the Act exempts certain construction projects related to Indian housing from the Davis-Bacon Act, with exceptions for existing contracts. SEC. 8 provides technical assistance. SEC. 8 authorizes grants for technical assistance to Indian tribes for housing programs, with an appropriation of $500,000.
